As for the great god, at that time the Venerable Udayin had this thought:
Now, which sentient beings are bound to me first to accept my teaching and transformation?
He observed that a Brahmin was serving the great god and was capable of being liberated.
At that time, Udayin, in the morning, took his robes and bowl, entered the city of Shravasti, and in order, went for alms. He saw that the Brahmin had prepared offerings.
He looked for the Brahmin and gave him food, loudly proclaiming:

Udayin said:

That person replied:

The two of them went together to the great heavenly image. Udayin asked:
Am I a Brahmin?
Then the great heavenly image spoke, saying:
Venerable Udayin!
You are truly a Brahmin, and your teacher is even more excellent, a great Brahmin.

When he saw the great heavenly image speak, he was greatly astonished and marveled at it as never before. He deeply gave rise to respect and faith in the Buddha's teachings, and then invited Udayin to his home for offerings.

After the meal, he was taught the Dharma, instructed, benefited, and delighted. Having heard the Dharma, he saw the truth and attained the first fruit. He took refuge in the Three Jewels and received the five precepts. Until the end of his life, he abstained from killing and so forth. He said:
Venerable!
I wish to provide all necessary things, food, clothing, bedding, and medicine for as long as I live. Please accept them.ğŸ”½He said:

As for the one with a large topknot, at another time, Venerable Udayin observed which sentient beings were suitable to be transformed.
He saw a brahmin who also served the great god and did not believe in the Three Jewels, knowing that he was suitable to be transformed.
In the morning, he took his robes and bowl and entered the city of Shravasti, and saw that brahmin setting out food as before, hoping to make offerings to a brahmin.
He said:
Who is a brahmin?
I will give them food.
Udayin said:
I am a brahmin, and my great teacher is the supreme brahmin.
That person replied:
You are not a brahmin, you are a shaven-headed monk.
If a true brahmin, they would not have such a form.
Udayin said:ğŸ”½I am a brahmin, and my great teacher is the supreme brahmin.

He replied:

Udayin said:

He touched his head, and the large topknot appeared like a crown.
Seeing this, the man deeply believed and felt it was a rare occurrence. He invited Udayin in to receive food.
After the meal, Udayin taught the Dharma, guiding and benefiting them. The brahmin and his wife both attained the first fruit.
Having attained the fruit, they took refuge in the Three Jewels and received the precepts. They offered the four requisites until the end of their lives.
The Venerable One said:
I have a mission.
He left.
As for the one who bought the pearl, at another time, Venerable Udayin observed who among sentient beings was suitable to be taught.
He saw a brahmin who also served the great god but did not believe in the Three Jewels. Knowing he was suitable to be taught,
In the morning, he took his robes and bowl and entered the city, standing outside the door of the brahmin's house.
Knowing that the wife wanted a good pearl, he immediately transformed his body into a pearl seller, entered her house, showed her a good pearl, its luster bright and its shape lovely, and said:
I am selling this pearl. If you need it, you can take it as you wish.
Then the brahmin asked for its price, and Udayin said:
Whatever price you offer.
When they offered a price that was not even a hundredth of the value, Udayin took their price.
Then the couple marveled at this unprecedented event and privately sighed to themselves:
Why would a valuable pearl be sold at such a low price?
Udayin, knowing that their faculties were ripe, then restored his original form. The couple's deep faith and respect doubled, and they finally offered him the finest food and drink.

After they had eaten, he recited the verses on giving and further expounded the profound Dharma. When the husband and wife heard it, they both attained the first fruit, took refuge and received the precepts, and made offerings for the rest of their lives, as explained in detail above.
Then Udayin left them and departed.

As for the doctor, at that time in the city of Shravasti there was a Brahmin who had no faith or respect in the Three Jewels. He suffered from a serious illness for many years, and all the doctors abandoned him, saying:
This is an incurable disease.
At that time the Brahmin no longer sought medical treatment, but waited to die upright.
Udayin observed that he was suitable for conversion. He took his robes and bowl and entered the city. He went to that family and stood outside the gate, transforming himself into a doctor and saying:
I am good at medical treatment.
The family members called him in. The sick person said:
I have been ill for a long time and all the doctors have abandoned me. I only know to wait for death and have no one to rely on.
The transformed doctor replied:ğŸ”½I am good at medical treatment.
You don't need to worry, the power of spells and good medicine is inconceivable, in an instant I will make you recover.
When the patient heard this, he was deeply delighted.
UdÄyin then recited the spell and praised the names of the Three Jewels. When the brÄhmaá¹‡a heard the spell, all his illnesses were cured and he recovered as before.
When the Venerable saw this, he returned to his original form. The couple in the house doubled their respect and admiration, and prepared delicious food to invite him to accept their offerings.
After the meal, he expounded the Dharma, and they both attained the first fruit. He accepted their refuge and precepts, as explained in detail above, and then left.

As for the assembly of monks, at that time in the city of ÅšrÄvastÄ« there was a brÄhmaá¹‡a who had no faith or respect for the Three Jewels. He was very wealthy and had much property, but his nature was stingy and he had no intention of giving in charity, preferring to hoard it all.
At that time, UdÄyin knew that his faculties were ripe, and he often went to his house to beg for alms, but despite his efforts he received nothing.
Later, on another day, he took his robes and bowl and went back to that family. He came out with an empty bowl, just reaching the door, when that brahmin came in from the outside and asked:
Bhiká¹£u!
Did you get anything in my house?
The Venerable one saw that he had no faith or respect, and secretly said to him:
Since you don't have it yourself, how can you give it to others?
Upon hearing this, he became angry and replied:
Monk!
I have wealth and food that can support everyone. Why do you say there is nothing and look down on me?
He answered:
If it's like that, I will come to your place tomorrow to receive food.
The brahmin said:
This is truly a good thing.
At that time, Udayi went to other families, obtained food, returned to his original place, finished eating, paid homage to the Buddha, and said:
World-Honored One!
There was a brahmin who did not believe in the Three Jewels. He was stingy by nature and made it his duty to hoard, without any thought of giving in charity.
Today he suddenly invited me, the Buddha, and the assembly of monks to come for a meal tomorrow morning.
The Buddha silently accepted.
The brahmin, having reached the next day, had not made any preparations in his house.
At that time, AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada and the other elders, having heard of the invitation to the Buddha and the monks, all went to his house and saw that there were no provisions. They said to the brahmin:
You invited Udayin and his retinue, which is the same as the Buddha and the assembly of monks coming to your house to receive a meal at one time.
Why is it that you have made no preparations now?
He replied:
I am not giving them food.
The people said:
If the Buddha and the assembly of monks come to your house today and you do not offer them food, King Prasenajit will certainly punish you and will not let you off.

At that time, the brÄhman, having heard this, was greatly afraid. Moreover, because of the wholesome roots from his past lives, he suddenly produced many things and prepared the best offerings to give to the Buddha and the saá¹…gha.
At that time, the World-Honored One, surrounded by the great assembly, went to his house in the morning, sat on the prepared seat, and sat in meditation.

At that time, Upatiá¹£ya stayed behind to sit and expound the wonderful Dharma for the couple. They both attained insight right there on their seats, took refuge in the Three Jewels, and accepted the five precepts, as explained in detail above.
As for belly, in the city of ÅšrÄvastÄ« there was a brÄhman who also had no respectful faith in the Three Jewels. His wife was upright and had few peers.
That person loved his wife very much and never allowed others to enter his house.

At that time, Udayin, as before, observed who was suitable for conversion. Seeing that the time had come for the liberation of that couple, he took his robe and bowl and went begging for food in sequence.
When he reached their door and was about to enter their house, the Brahmin saw him and did not allow him in, so he went to urinate.

At that time, Udayin caused him to urinate without stopping, and then entered the house to face his wife. The wife was arrogant and did not look at him. Udayin transformed the wife's intestines to come out of her abdomen.
Then the Brahmin came to see and was frightened, giving rise to a mind of disgust, and finally bowed to the Venerable One, requesting to repent and apologize.
Udayin then withdrew his spiritual transformation, causing the wife's body to recover as before. The couple marveled at it as never before.
Udayin expounded the Dharma for them, saying that the body is impure and there is nothing to be cherished. The couple heard the Dharma and both attained the first fruit, as explained in detail above.
As for climbing the ladder, there was a Brahmin in the city of ÅšrÄvastÄ« whose wife was beautiful, but the wife had no faith or respect in her heart.

He observed that the couple had good roots from past lives, were bound to him, and were suitable to be transformed, so he took his robe and bowl and went to their house.
At that time, the Brahmin had something to do and went out first. The Venerable One then entered their house.
When the wife saw him from afar, she avoided him and entered the room. The Venerable One also entered.
The wife then climbed the ladder and went up to the high loft, and the Venerable One also went up.
The wife then pushed the ladder to make it stand upright. At that time, the Venerable One fell to the ground and entered the concentration of cessation.
At that time, the wife looked from afar and saw that he was not breathing, thinking he was already dead.

She went down the ladder and held him with her hands. Although she used all her strength, she could not move him at all. She then told the family members to come together and lift him, but they also could not move him.

At that time, the brÄhmaá¹‡a came from outside, startled and amazed at the matter. After briefly asking about it, he himself supported [the body] but was also unable to lift it. The family was frightened and had no way to plan.
At that time, there was a brÄhmaá¹‡a upÄsaka who was his acquaintance. He came from outside.
Seeing Venerable UdÄyin, he said to the host:

At that time, the brÄhmaá¹‡a grasped [UdÄyin's] feet, bowed his head to the ground, sought pity, and repented. Venerable [UdÄyin] came out of concentration and expounded the Dharma for him. He then attained the first fruit, as explained in detail above.
As for enjoying, in ÅšrÄvastÄ« there was a brÄhmaá¹‡a who married a woman from a prominent family as his wife. Her appearance was outstanding, and she was proud of herself.

The Venerable One, in accordance with her karmic conditions from past lives, spoke a verse, saying:

You have seen beautiful women with tears wetting their collars, and before long you will also cry yourself.
After speaking the verse, he left through the door.
At that time, that woman did not understand the meaning of the words and thought like this:
This Å›ramaá¹‡a is scolding me.
With a mind full of anger, when the brahmin returned he saw and asked:
What is the matter?
The wife said:
Earlier there was a Å›ramaá¹‡a who came and scolded me. If he is still alive, my life is not complete.
When her husband heard this, he glared angrily, drew his sharp sword, and chased after the bhiká¹£u, wanting to kill him.
At that time, Udayin saw him coming from afar, transformed into a small room, closed the door and sat down. The brÄhmaá¹‡a called out, asking him to open the door. The Venerable One said:

He then put down his sword, and with extreme anger, urgently called out to open the door.
The Venerable One replied:

Having heard this, he secretly thought:

He then repented and removed his harmful thoughts, and the door was opened for him.
After he entered, the Venerable One spoke the wonderful Dharma for him, and he attained the first fruit. He accepted the three refuges and five precepts, and said:

Now listen carefully!
I will explain it to you.
Long ago there was a poor woman who saw a beautiful woman adorned with gorgeous ornaments, attended by servants, and loved and respected by many people.
The poor woman was distressed and wept, thinking like this:
'By what means can I obtain such things as I desire?'
At that time there was a lay disciple who was her friend and said to her:
'Why are you so worried?'
The woman told her what had happened, and she replied:
'Worrying is useless. The fruits of others arise from their causes.'
The poor woman asked:

She replied:

At that time, a solitary enlightened sage came to beg for food. The woman gave him food, hoping for something in return.
The solitary enlightened one then manifested a spiritual transformation for her. The poor woman gave rise to faith and made a vow, saying:
I wish that by the wholesome roots of this offering, wherever I am born, I will not encounter poverty and suffering.

Because of the power of your wife's past karmic actions and vows, she has obtained the reward of upright appearance and abundant enjoyments, and is born into a noble clan, cherished by people.

At that time, the brahmin having obtained the supreme fruit, and hearing about the events of his past lives, invited the Venerable One to return to his original dwelling and prepared various kinds of the most delicious food and drink for him.

When the brÄhmaá¹‡a heard this, he returned home and scolded his wife:

The wife then said:

When her husband heard this, he deeply wondered at her words and wanted to test whether they were true or false.

As for the violent one, there was a Brahmin in the city of Shravasti whose wife was of violent nature.
On the day of the festival, the Brahmin had this thought:

Having had this thought, he took his son and avoided going to another village.
Udayin observed that the time had come for the woman's transformation, so he took his robes and bowl to her house. Seeing the woman preparing food and drink,

At that time, the Venerable One opened both eyes as wide as a bowl. The woman said again:

The brahmin knew that the festival day had passed, and he came together with his son. Seeing his wife's dignified and silent demeanor, observing her actions which were unusual compared to usual times, he spoke a verse, saying:

The Venerable One, out of compassion, accepted it and left.

The Venerable One replied:

Then, the Venerable One transformed various pure food and drink into his own bowl and said to the people:

Who is without discrimination?
When the young men heard these words, they each examined themselves and knew their own vulgarity. They said to each other:
It is the Venerable One's spiritual power that has transformed our flower garlands and food and drink into various impure things that are inedible.
We have no other plan now, so we should go to him and apologize.
They then bowed at his feet and said:

We are foolish and ignorant, with the eyes of flesh, relying on our own family and caste, we spoke vulgar and evil words, and rashly slighted you. We only pray that you will have compassion and accept our apology.
They spoke a verse with the same voice, saying:

All the same, a body of impurity, how can there be a distinction of the four castes?
If the body is free from evil, and the mouth also has no offenses;
The mind is extremely pure, this is called a true brahmin.
Adorned with the supreme and wonderful Dharma, well-disciplined and cultivating pure conduct;
Able to remove all evil karma, this is a true brahmin.

At that time, Udayin heard the verse and knew that their faculties were ripe, so he spoke the Dharma for them, teaching, benefiting, and delighting them. The five hundred youths then, on their seats, severed their afflictions and saw the truth.
Their bodies and food and drink became pure as before, and they each received the precepts of refuge, as explained in detail above.

As for the bowl, in the city of ÅšrÄvastÄ« there was a brÄhmaá¹‡a who was skilled in spells and did not believe in the Three Jewels. He always used his magical powers to drive ghosts and spirits, making them pull his cart and travel as he wished.

The Venerable One took the bowl and showed it to him, saying:

The Brahmin said:
This black iron bowl, how can it serve me?
The Venerable One said:
Whatever you think of, it will all come out of this.
When he heard these words, he immediately tried to think of food of a hundred flavors. As soon as he thought of it, the bowl was filled with all kinds of flavors.
Seeing this, he marveled at the unprecedented event and said:
Great Sage!
I wish you would bestow upon me this wonderful method.
The Venerable One then spoke a verse to him, saying:
The bright mantra is not given to others, it is exchanged with a mantra and then given,
Sometimes one obtains service, or gains many precious treasures,
If it is not like this, even if one dies, it is not transmitted.
At that time, having heard the verses, the brÄhmaá¹‡a carefully contemplated in order to seek the mantra, thinking:
Knowing the inconceivable power of the divine mantra, since it is not given to others, how can I obtain it?
He said to the Venerable One:

The Venerable One replied:

For the sake of the mantra, he went forth according to the teaching. After shaving his beard and hair and donning the Dharma robes, he said to his teacher:

Give me the clear mantra.
The teacher said:

The disciple said:

The teacher said:

This is the bright mantra in the bowl. During the three nights, you diligently cultivate and practice it. There will surely be spiritual manifestations. You should contemplate the meaning of these phrases well.

At that time, the disciple, seeking spiritual manifestations in hopes of success, single-mindedly and continuously contemplated the three phrases of the Dharma day and night. He wonderfully understood the true source and eliminated various delusions, realizing arhatship. He then went to the teacher, bowed at his feet, and said:

UdÄyin said:ğŸ”½Excellent!
Excellent!

As for wrestling, at that time there was a strong man who came from the south, wanting to find someone to compete in strength in the central country.
